conclusion: Millikan proved the quantization of electric charge by observing the motion of oil droplets.
The experiment involves two metal plates placed horizontally with a separation of d, and oil droplets sprayed through a hole in the upper plate.
Oil droplets acquire electric charges due to collisions or friction.
Two spherical oil droplets, A and B, each with mass m_0, are located on the same vertical line.
Droplets fall with uniform velocity through a distance h_1 within time t.
A voltage U is applied across the plates, causing B to move upwards with uniform velocity.
B rises through a distance h_2 in time t, then merges with A to form a new droplet.
The magnitude of air resistance on a droplet is given by f=k m^{1/3}v.
Air buoyancy is negligible, and acceleration due to gravity is g.
The image shows two metal plates with a small hole in the upper plate and droplets A and B between them.
The upper plate is connected to the positive terminal and the lower plate to the negative terminal.
Since A continues to fall at its original velocity, the forces acting on it are balanced.
For droplet B, the upward motion indicates an unbalanced force due to the electric field.
The electric force on B must be equal to the sum of gravitational force and air resistance for it to move upwards uniformly.
The new droplet formed after merging A and B will have a mass of 2m_0.
Using the formula for air resistance, f=k m^{1/3}v, we can express the forces acting on the droplets.
The proportionality constant k can be derived from the balance of forces on droplet B.
The final expression for k is derived as k = (3U)/(2gh_1).
